From the explanation in the Video it sounds like this could well really be an  "Introduction to Computer technology / Computers in Society, Literacy, and History"  crash course,  rather than a Computer Science one,   Because your speaker literally said "this isn't a Computing course... but we're going to talk about the History"...........  It'd be like saying you'll call something a Physics crash course or a Calculus crash course but you decide to just have the  biographies of a bunch of famous scientists or mathematicians  without expounding out the Laws of motion,  Other important equations,  Or the  details of the maths,  That's called a History course,  not a Science or Math course!;     Please don't use the name "Computer Science"  for that.   It's just a Dishonest name to call it.  Not that the historical context  of the Science of Information and Computation is Unimportant --- It's just that History and social context of computing without computing itself  Has nothing to do with  --  Computer Science   not  Unless  there's actual reaching coverage of the nitty gritty actual hard Science aspect that makes CS a Science and not just a hands-on Engineering field,   The detailed science of the computing and information theory -----       For a  true course on  "Computer Science"       ought to be  Including things such as  fundamental foundations in the Philosophy and Mathematics,  common Data structures including Stacks, Queues, Trees, Heaps, and Graphs, their usage and operation, details common Algorithms (eg  Qsort, A* Search,  Hash tables,  Lossy and Lossless compression).  Important Theorems and Proofs,   Mathematical details on the complexity analysis of algorithms, and related notations, Loops Recurrence and Recursion,  Turing machines/Church-Turing Thesis, Abstractions,  the concepts of Programming language and Parsers,  Decidability / Chomsky Type-0 recursively enumerable languages vs partially decidable vs semidecidable, Number systems,    Data types and binary operations and data representations,  Forward Error Correction+Erasure coding,  Logical systems, Automata theory, Computability,  P vs NP,  Functional Programming concepts,  OO Programming concepts,   Software engineering concepts,  And yes,  some Actual details of how some basic programs are written in at least a few programming languages,  how to write some basic assembly and real machine language,  concepts such as the Stack,  Frame pointer, Shift registers,  Etc, Etc.....
As a student in the field, I'll be looking forward to this series.

Initially, I was overwhelmed by the backdrop (oscilloscopes, etc) and pretense of how CS was explained here. As a CS grad, I really hope that this exhibits machines as tools for demonstrating computer science, rather than "here's how to program." Drop the tech, and explain what's really going on.  Explain discrete mathematics. Show us the philosophers throughout history who developed the ideas that eventually led to Alan Turing's foundation for modern algorithms. All of these ideas existed centuries before modern transistors. THAT is really cool stuff that most people aren't exposed to. This is what I'm looking forward to.

"[...] the topic became – primarily in the USA – prematurely known as ‘computer science’ – which, actually, is like referring to surgery as ‘knife science’ – and it was firmly implanted in people's minds that computing science is about machines and their peripheral equipment. [...] We now know that a programmable computer is no more and no less than an extremely handy device for realizing any conceivable mechanism without changing a single wire, and that the core challenge for computing science is hence a conceptual one, viz., what (abstract) mechanisms we can conceive without getting lost in the complexities of our own making."  - Edsger Dijkstra
